text: Hello. We clearly need a failsafe protection in splice itself to not poluate the PG DBs if a "migrating: true" is forgotten. Because having to clean the DBs in case of missed step is inefficient and too complicated. Same for old participant DB removal. I'd say we need a flag to tell participant itself to remove participant_PreviousMigrationId

elements.text: Hello. We clearly need a failsafe protection in splice itself to not poluate the PG DBs if a "migrating: true" is forgotten. Because having to clean the DBs in case of missed step is inefficient and too complicated. Same for old participant DB removal. I'd say we need a flag to tell participant itself to remove participant_PreviousMigrationId

text:
for those who use Loki in Grafana stack
```count_over_time({pod=~"validator-app.*"} |= `DomainMigrationDump` [1m])```
loki rule to catch DomainMigrationDump text from the log when thats happens, i can tell that helped me on the last 2 upgrades.

text: Well, to be precise, participant DB could be named whatever you like, but never reused when changing migration ID. So easier way is to bump the suffix or stop participant and wipe its DB

elements.text: Well, to be precise, participant DB could be named whatever you like, but never reused when changing migration ID. So easier way is to bump the suffix or stop participant and wipe its DB

text: For validator, the same DB is used accross migration-id changes, but its schema is updated. And if you loose it, you loose your wallet

elements.text: For validator, the same DB is used accross migration-id changes, but its schema is updated. And if you loose it, you loose your wallet

text: But a better way should be : participant knows current migration_id. validator knows its last known migration_id from its DB and sees that migration-id was bumped in its own config. If they both agree they are compatible (code version and migration-id, do the DB mutation step

text: Why is necessary to set `migration.migrating=true` (k8s) or start with `-M` (docker-compose) at all? Surely the node can see that its on-disk data is for ex. MIGRATION_ID=2 and the SVs are on MIGRATION_ID=3, at which point it shouldn't need a human to tell it to upgrade.

elements.text: Why is necessary to set
migration.migrating=true
(k8s) or start with
-M
(docker-compose) at all? Surely the node can see that its on-disk data is for ex. MIGRATION_ID=2 and the SVs are on MIGRATION_ID=3, at which point it shouldn't need a human to tell it to upgrade.

text: TBH I don't really understand why any of this needs human intervention. I'm not saying that canton should go full <https://github.com/cosmos/cosmos-sdk/blob/main/tools/cosmovisor/README.md|cosmovisor> (having the application automatically install new binaries and switch to them always struck me as a step too far), but the number of manual steps seems pointlessly excessive.

text:
Hi Canton team

When we setting up the validator following the docs in here: <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/index.html> It mentions nothing about the signing key of the operator party. The operator party that usually form the name of `<party-hint>::<some-hash>`  The person who setting up the validator now ultimately have access to the reward. Or they can also bind another user on OIDC system to that operator party, so they can also login to wallet, and control the asset (liveness reward at least) of the operator party.

The participant of this operator party has the id in form of `PAR::<party-hint>::<validator-id>` , When I look into the database, or when taking an identity dump(by passing the bearer token we acquire through OIDC system), we can extract out these key: signing key.

Is there a way to:

a) setting up external wallet/party for this operator party so that the signing key won't appear in our database. and cannot be extracted through the identity dump.

or b) if we cannot use external party for that, is there a way to control this signing key generation such as we generate it manually before setting up the validator. Then we configure the validator bootstrap in a way to use them instead ?

elements.text:
Hi Canton team

When we setting up the validator following the docs in here:
It mentions nothing about the signing key of the operator party. The operator party that usually form the name of
<party-hint>::<some-hash>

The person who setting up the validator now ultimately have access to the reward. Or they can also bind another user on OIDC system to that operator party, so they can also login to wallet, and control the asset (liveness reward at least) of the operator party.

The participant of this operator party has the id in form of
PAR::<party-hint>::<validator-id>

, When I look into the database, or when taking an identity dump(by passing the bearer token we acquire through OIDC system), we can extract out these key: signing key.

Is there a way to:

a) setting up external wallet/party for this operator party so that the signing key won't appear in our database. and cannot be extracted through the identity dump.

or b) if we cannot use external party for that, is there a way to control this signing key generation such as we generate it manually before setting up the validator. Then we configure the validator bootstrap in a way to use them instead ?
